text: @malcor84 Totally agree in regards to bad behaviour in both genders.  What Gillette and your friend is focusing on is toxicity of men rather than addressing the toxicity of both sexes.  The funny thing about the advert is that blokes just want a shave and avoid being nicked.  Unfortunately, Gillette want us men to think that we’re arseholes whilst shaving.  You don’t expect Pretty Polly to advertise their product by telling women not expect a man to pay for everything on a date because equality means equality, therefore spilt the bill.  I wonder how many women would complain.

@marmitefan88 I think my daughter's situation only shows that both boys and girls are capable of poor behavior. My fight has been with the school who seems to be incapable of doing anything about it themselves.

@malcor84 Maybe you should inform your friend @penelopefaux to concentrate on the toxic girls in your daughter’s school for being bullied than the other guy’s reaction to the advert.  It’s ironic that the advert shows male toxicity in bullying when all along it’s the girls who are bullying your daughter.  Unfortunately your friend is blinkered; surprisingly she hasn’t commented on your daughter’s bullying, and I wonder why.
@malcor84 thank you Matt. 💜

@penelopefaux I don’t see women stand up to other women when they’re out of line.  Two months ago I was in the company of 10 women; a female colleague made a racial comment about me not realising I was standing in front of her.  None of the other women said anything other than an embarrassing giggles.  Not one female stepped up and said “Hey, that’s bang out of order, we think you should apologise.” Rather getting on you high horse and telling us your interpretation of the advert, maybe you females should get your house in order before start judging men on their translation of the advert.  Women feel entitled to slap a man, verbally abusive to a man and expect us men not to retaliate.  This makes feminine toxicity worse.

@wiltshire_waif and @adventures_await_771, @penelopefaux and I have actually known each other since kindergarten haha. I respect her opinion as much as any bodies and welcome the discussion. The ability to discuss our different views and opinions is what is really missing in today's social and political climate and she has every right to voice hers. She is a someone I actually have a deep respect for and has accomplished great things :)

@penelopefaux You are wrong and so is your knee jerk reaction to this man for voicing his feelings.  I know many men who are boycotting this ad not because they I identify with the these behaviors but because they do not.  They resent being told they need to do better.  You may want to analyze the ad again and the men who find it offensive.  There is a deeper message that goes beyond your initial conclusions.  The ad was pandering to you and your generalizations about males that is why you feel so good about yourself for embracing its message and condemning those who may have a different view of males than your view.

@malcor84 You do not have to explain or defend your feelings to this woman. She can't tell you how to feel or explain why a razor company is trying to is jumping into politics and patronizing and blatantly insulting and degrading 50% of the population in a way they could never do with any other group. That women are trying to defend it and further patronize men by suggesting they have all just taken it wrong is the equivalent of of the whole "can't you take a joke". It is so offensive.

@malcor84 so that's something interesting that I agree with you completely on. There's a lot of pressure on men to provide financially, be physically/emotionally strong and have sexual stamina etc. I also agree that the to me gender equality is the point. I want men to feel safe and supported as well as women. I think a strong barrier to that are the toxic traits discussed.

@penelopefaux apologies again, been a crazy busy night here at work. I think the fact that I don't have these traits is why I find it so offensive. I don't like generalizations and feel that this ad isn't targeting some troublesome men, but all in general. The pressure put onto modern men to be perfect is really understated in media and frankly it's why so many have become content with being alone. I walk through Target and see every shape of female maniquin imaginable, from petite to plus size, yet a cannot buy a shirt there that isn't a slim or athletic fit. It's the demand for equality yet the silent double standard that I find completely exhausting. I've raised and will continue to raise my daughter to know that she can be whatever she wants to be and if she fails in those goals, it's her own actions that prevent her success.
Good for you, you didn’t miss the point of 💩.

@malcor84 let me say this. You've always struck me as the type of man that this ad was saying to strive for. If you're not exerting these toxic traits which I tend to gather you aren't... Then why is it bothersome? If you're the better man that this ad is discussing, then take that as point of pride and be a role model to other men and your daughter. It's so simple

@malcor84 that's the thing. That's not what the ad says at all. It's only addressing the toxic traits of men. Being a good father and husband are the great things about being a man. No one wants to take masculinity away. Masculinity should not be equated with violence and sexual harassment. That's the issue it's addressing. So that your little girl doesn't grow up in a world where she doesn't feel safe to walk alone or concerned that her worth is related to her body. To me, real masculinity is found in the strength a man has to hold a family together, to show tenderness and respect to women and to teach his boys the same.

@penelopefaux sorry I wasn't ignoring you, just on my way to work. To elaborate, my issue with this ad is that it tells me to look in the mirror and be ashamed that a man is looking back at me, despite the fact that I'm a husband and father who works tirelessly to provide my family, of which two members are female, with everything they need. My daughter comes home in tears from school often because she's been picked on, but guess what? It's not little boys picking on her, but other girls, some of them even older than her. Yet I hear nothing of this in the media. I don't like the idea that societies salvation lies in the idea that exclusively men need to be "better" and that we all need to be androgynous and not embrace our differences. I love that women are different than men. I embrace both sexes strengths and weaknesses. Yet I'm constantly told I should be ashamed of being male.

@adventures_await_771 so funny to be called triggered when the entire point I made was that this ad only triggers a boycott by boys that identify with the toxic traits that it set out to shed light on. I'm disappointed because I had made a wrong assumption that Matt was a better man than that.
@penelopefaux Triggered much?  Is he not allowed to have is feeling and express himself?  #toxicfeminism

@malcor84 I'm really shocked and disappointed by your reaction to an add that literally says men are better than this. That men should be standing up to each other when they are of of line. That it's not ok to teach boys that they are not allowed to cry and that it's not ok for men to treat women poorly. That's literally all it was about.

@penelopefaux a I can do is vote with my dollar. When a company goes out of its way to depict all men as animals, well I'll do what I can to show my disappointment. Not only that, but I'm sick of politics and a razor company has no logical business making ads like this.
Ooh boy... 🤦‍♀️🙄 Ya really missed the point on this one buddy
